question: How is the level of horizontal equipment checked across the machined face of nozzle flanges?
ground_truth: The level of horizontal equipment is checked across the machined face of nozzle flanges with a precision level.
contexts:
1 mm per metre height, subject to maximum of 6 mm.

4.6.4 Horizontal equipment shall be checked for level across machined face of nozzle flanges with

precision level.

4.6.5 Difference in elevation of centerline from one end to the other end shall not be more than 1 mm per meter and limited to ± 3 mm maximum. Further elevation difference shall be such as to ensure complete draining of equipment.

4.6.6 Survey of column inside and checking the levelness of support rings, location of bolting bars to ensure that the same are as per column drawings and within tolerances specified in standard 7-14-0001. In case these are not within permissible tolerances, the same shall be reported to EIC for necessary rectification/modification.

4.7 (cid:9)

Safety, Health & Environment

EC shall install an exhaust fan for exhaling welding/ cutting fumes etc. and to maintain adequate oxygen level, before any work is started inside confined spaces (i.e. columns). Adequate ventilation shall be maintained at all times. Gas/LPG cylinders shall not be taken inside confined space. When a worker/supervisor enters a confined space, it shall be mandatory to have a second man as standby. Safety belts shall be worn while entering columns, if there is a danger of falling. All ladders/stair cases shall be in place before any item is offered to owner's inspectors. Rope ladders/scaffolding shall be provided inside the column in case tower internals are not easily approachable from column manhole. Low voltage (24 V) lamps equipped with guards shall be used to prevent accidental contact with bulb. All electrical connections shall be through ELCB's and proper earthing shall be ensured. Acids and other materials used for pickling shall be disposed off to a designated place as directed by owner/EIL. All statutory Regulations and owner's safety, health and environment requirements

question: What was the impact of the additional CP system requirement for the Brown Field and Green Field Service Water and Service Air Lines on the project's timeline and scope, specifically regarding delays and changes in deliverables?
ground_truth: The additional CP system requirement for the Brown Field and Green Field Service Water and Service Air Lines constituted a variation to the contract. For the Brown Field, the change in location of the tie-in and the subsequent requirement to change the routing from above ground to below ground led to the laying of underground piping, which was completed and signed off by 30 September 2021. For the Green Field, the relocation of the workshop required additional underground piping for road crossing, which was designed and completed. These changes impacted the project's timeline and scope by introducing additional requirements and modifications to the original design.
contexts:
Start Date – 29 April 2021

Delay Finish Date – 20 November 2021

Total Duration- 206 Calendar days

Introduction of Delay Event:

This delay event is completely unforeseen and was initiated by additional requirements by the Company at the execution stage. The Contractor has been instructed by the Company to comply with the Company’s directions in relation to installation of pressure gauges and Associated fitting in Main Gas line.

Chronology of Delay Event:

During the engineering meeting held on 21 February 2021, the issue of requirement of tight shut off valve for Fuel gas and HC gas line was raised by the Company and Contractor informed that additional requirements are not necessary.

During the execution stage, the Company instructed to install Pressure Gauges and associated fittings on the Main Gas and Pre-chamber line. The Contractor notified on 29 April 2021 vide ZPTE/OLNG/ LTR-229 that there will be time and cost implication for this change and there are reworks involved as well in addition to procurement of long lead items such as Equal Tee CS, Flange CS, Spool pipe CS, Mono flange and Pressure gauge.

The Contractor asserts that the Company approved design is technically complied and were discussed between all the Project stakeholders in many design workshops noted below:

Design review dated 19 June 2019

HAZOP dated 18 August 2019

Model Review dated 10 March 2020

IPF dated 11 December 2019

The Company responded on 04 May 2021 vide 6A05/ OLNG/ ZPTE/ LTR/ 0241 that “All the non-compliances or deficiencies or omissions revealed at any stage during the execution of the CONTRACT shall be corrected by the Contractor at their cost. The Contractor is not in agreement with the Company’s statement which in such instances renders the Contractor’s entitlement under Clause 18 [Variations] redundant.

As the matter of installation of Pressure Gauges and Associated fitting in Main Gas line and Variation request was resolved on 20th November 2021.

Contractual Justification

Referring to the Clause 18 of the GCC, which provides for Extension of the Time for completion of the work carried out by the Contractor; the Contractor’s works were impacted by additional requirements of installation of pressure gauges and Associated fitting in Main Gas line. Therefore, the Contractor is considering the impact of permits on the work schedule and hereby submitting its entitlement to extension of time pursuant to the Clause 31.biz of the GCC.



DE-37: Mobilization of Vendors

Delay Period

Delay Start Date – 29th April 2021

Delay Finish Date – 30th June 2021

Total Duration- 63 Calendar days

Introduction of Delay Event:

Due to the global pandemic COVID-19, Government issued regulations through Supreme Committee in order to control spread of COVID-19. The effect of COVID-19 has not ceased and restrictions imposed by the Supreme Committee from time to time has affected mobilisation of vendors. Further, complete travel ban from many countries to Oman are enforced which has caused delays to mobilization activities by various vendors and the Contractor’s own resources as well.

Chronology of Delay Event:

This is in continuous with delay events under force majeure events claimed

The Contractor’s progress of works was further impacted by restrictions on visa issuance by the Supreme Committee vide ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-220 dated 18 April 2021.

Further, the Subcontractor’s vendors were unable to proceed for as-planned works after detection of COVID-19 positive cases for their staffs which were notified to the Company vide ZPTE/OLNG/LTR-231 dated 03 May 2021. Thus, the mobilization of vendors were affected and impacted the Contractor’s progress against Rev-Q Programme. Some of the examples which were affected by above are presented below.

Engine Hall Doors:

The Engine Hall Doors Were Delivered to site by 27 April 2021 for the installation and the Contractor’s plan was to mobilize the vendor for installation on 5 May 2021. However, the mobilization of the vendor resources for the installation were delayed due to the detection of COVID cases. Despite of the efforts taken for the replacement of proposed resources, due to the spread of the Second wave the availability of resources was difficult. This had an impact on the progress of works for which the Contractor considers entitled for additional time.

Lube Oil Flushing

The Contractor would like to inform the Company that Lube Oil Vendor scheduled for mobilization on 25 April 2021 was rescheduled to 30 April 2021 due to the delay in delivery of level instruments because of COVID-19 at Supplier’s warehouse facilities.  Again, the Mobilization was delayed due to the detection of COVID-19 case in

the Subcontractor’s crew. This had an impact on the progress of works for which the Contractor considers entitled for additional time.

Monoplane valves

The Contractor has appointed TPI to expedite the progress, however the Delivery of alternate Seals to carryout retest is getting delayed because of COVID and also to note that the Manufacturer Facility in India is under lockdown since 10 April 2021 due to the local Government instructions. Since then, the testing and assembly is on hold. This is having an impact on the CCC and commencement of the commissioning activities.

FAT - PACO System:



The Contractor further notified that ongoing DCS FAT in YMA at Bahrain is suspended since 03 May 2021 due COVID Case in the Facilities. Presently we understand from YME that, their facility will be under lockdown till 8th May 2021. 

As event continued to affect the works critically until 30th June 2021.

Contractual Justification

Referring to the Clause 19 of the GCC, which provides for Extension of the Time for completion of the work carried out by the Contractor; the Contractor’s works were impacted by the COVID-19 Force Majeure event which was unforeseen and beyond the control of either party.

Therefore, the Contractor is considering the impact of COVID-19 on the work schedule and hereby submitting its entitlement to extension of time pursuant to the Clause 31.biz of the GCC.

DE-38: CP system Requirement at BF Service water Line

Delay Period

Delay Start Date – 12th December 2021

Delay Finish Date – 31st August 2022

Total Duration- 263 Calendar days

Introduction of Delay Event:

This delay event pertains to the requirement of additional CP system at Brown Field and Green Filed for Service Air and Service water Line. On 05 December 2021, vide OLNG email, ZPTE was instructed to provide the CP for the underground piping when all construction and pre-commissioning works for these lines were completed as per the approval received from OLNG and moreover, all buried piping was coated with approved coating specifications. Therefore, the CP system Requirement at BF Service water Line constitutes variation to the Contract.

Chronology of Delay Event:

Brown Field – Requirement of CP for Service Water Line

As per original design, the Tie‐in for Service water (Tie in 045-03) is located inside Train‐3 service water distribution header. Accordingly, as per the original scope, the Isometric / PEFS drawings were prepared and approved.

To perform the Tie‐in as per the original design, Train 3 shutdown was required.   OLNG advised to change the tie location as OLNG was not able to provide the Train 3 Shutdown and mutually agreed to change the location of tie in. Accordingly, the TQ 755 was raised on 11 November 2020 and approved on 12 November 2020. This TQ was for change in location.

According to the TQ 755, the piping ISO drawing was prepared for the above ground piping.

During execution as per the above ISO, the joint visit was carried out by the EPC and PMC and during the joint visit it was found that, one of the existing pneumatic valves was fouling for Man access and advised to change the routing from above ground to below ground.

As per the instruction of the PMC, the TQ 773 raised on 21 Dec 2020 to change the above ground piping to below ground piping and approved on 3rd February 2021. This TQ clearly indicated the painting system for underground piping.



Upon approval of the TQ the under-ground piping (12 m) was laid with PCS 5 and work was completed and CCC signed on 30 September 2021.

The MCC for the same was also completed and signed on 12 Dec 2021.

All piping work for the Brown Field works were completed as per the approved TQ. Accordingly, CCC and MCC were signed by the Company.

The Contractor on 25 April 2022 informed Company that Change in location in comparison to approved design was documented in Project change management system and the Contractor submitted DCN on 13 February 2022 that is pending the Company.

Green Field – Requirement of CP for Service Water and Service Air Line

As per the Original Design the workshop is located at North-west corner and the same is shown in plot plan Rev 4. As per the plot plan Rev 4 there is no requirement of the underground piping.

The Company commented to relocate the workshop towards the South East Corner and due to this there was an additional requirement of Road crossing, the Service Water (20M) and Service Air Line (20 M) piping which were designed underground.  Accordingly, piping drawings / ISO were prepared with PCS 05. Subsequently, painting and construction and installation completed.

question:
What must contractors ensure about liquor/drug transactions under Oman's laws?"  
output: "What should contractors check re: liquor/drug laws in Oman?
ground_truth: Contractors must ensure that they do not import, sell, give, barter, or otherwise dispose of any alcoholic liquor or drugs, except in accordance with the Laws of the Sultanate of Oman. They must also ensure that their subcontractors, agents, or employees do not engage in such activities.

question: What's essential protective gear for handling chemicals in cooling water systems?
ground_truth: Normal safety precautions should be taken for handling of chemicals. Protective clothing and safety items should be used to prevent any injury during the pretreatment operation.
contexts:
solids are < 30ppm or close to make up water quality.

5.0

PHOSPHATE / PHOSPHONATE CLEANING CUM PASSIVATION

5.1

The pH of the circulating water should be adjusted to around 7.5 (7.5 – 8.0) by reducing the acid dose and should be held in this range through out the phosphate / phosphonate cleaning operation. All blows down from the system should be closed.

5.2

5% organo phosphonate (HEDP) should be added by gravity to build up a level of 80-100 mg/l as PO4.

**

HEDP – Hydroxy Ethylidene Diphosphonic Acid. Organophosphonate (HEDP) should be dosed very slowly as this will depress the pH of C.W. If necessary, caustic soda may be added in C.W. system to maintain pH in the range of 7.0-8.0.

5.3

5% Sodium Hexametaphosphate (SHMP) clean solution should be added to build up a level of 40-50 mg/l as PO4 Sodium Hexametaphosphate should be dosed after HEDP addition is complete and pH is stabilized.

5.4 When phosphate/ phosphonate level and pH are stabilized by preferably Ethylene oxide based non-ionic surfactant or Alkyl Aryl sulphonate based anionic surface active agent @ 30 ppm based on total hold up should be dosed. This should also be dosed at the same rate again after 24 hrs. This may produce foam in the system hence precaution shall be taken for operation of C.W. pumps. This shall be added slowly.

5.5

Circulation should be continued under this condition for a period of 7 days and following levels of chemicals shall be maintained in C.W. system for this period.

-

40-50 mg/l Sodium hexametaphosphate (SHMP) as PO4 80-100 mg/l Organo phosphonate as PO4 (HEDP, 50-60% active acid content)

-

pH Non-ionic/Anionic Surfactant* (Calculated quantity) *Shall be added twice only as given in item 5.4

7.5 –8.0 30 mg/l

5.6

After circulating for seven days, the system should be heavily blows down without pH adjustment and regular treatment should be started when TSS is being less than 30 mg/l or close to make up water quality HEDP is less than 10mg/l as PO4.

6.0 MONITORING

pH, phosphate and phosphonate level should be monitored regularly through out the entire operation and recommended levels should be maintained.

question: Which flange rating and orifice type fit ISO 5167 for low Reynolds?
ground_truth: Quadrant edge or conical entrance orifice plates shall be used for services with low Reynolds number.
contexts:
the limits as laid down by ISO 5167. The orifice plate primary element shall generally be thin plate, square-edge concentric orifices plate mounted between a pair of weld-neck type orifice flanges with flange taps. The minimum pressure rating of flanges shall be 300 ASME class. Process tapping shall be flange tapping as per ISO5167. For orifice Plates where D-D/2 taps are required and for all restriction orifices, the ratings of the orifice flanges shall be as per piping specification and the flanges shall be procured by Piping. Eccentric / Segmental type of orifice plates shall be used for specific applications. Quadrant edge or conical entrance orifice plates shall be used for services with low Reynolds number.

4.5 CONTROL VALVES

4.5.1 GENERAL

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Control valves shall normally be Globe type single seated. For clean services, guiding shall be top and bottom/cage type. For highly viscous services, cage guiding shall be avoided. Characteristic Ball valves shall be considered for services where solids in suspension, high rangeability, low pressure drops are required. Butterfly valves shall be considered for services where solids in suspension, low pressure drops and high capacities are required. Angle valves shall be considered for services where flashing, coking, solids in suspension or very large pressure drops are encountered. For control valve, on-off valve and self actuated pressure control valves, pressure rating of body and flanges shall be minimum 300 ASME class or as per respective piping specification whichever is higher. Bellow seal type valve shall be used for H2S service and shall be explored for H2 service and PSA valves also.

4.5.3 TRIM DESIGNS

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Material used for Trim shall be minimum 316 SS, with guide bushing of hardened stainless steel like 440 C, 17-4 PH all up to a pressure drop of 10 kg/cm2. For higher pressure drops or erosive and slurry services and in general for all steam services, hard-surfacing of plug, seal rings and sealing area of inner valve with stellite shall be used. Special cases may require 17-4 PH seat ring and 440 C solid plugs or other materials like Hastelloy, Monel etc. Multi-stage trims shall be used for where large differentials (> 40 kg/sq.cm) are encountered on case to case basis. For valves in services encountering particulate carry over along with high pressure drop, axial flow path trim design shall be used with angle body for continuous applications and globe body for intermittent applications.

Except as provided for under Clause 51 and 58 (I) hereof the quantities as set out in the Bill of Quantities are to be taken as to be the actual and correct quantities of the work to be executed by the Contractor in fulfillment of his obligations under the Contract. Any error in description or in quantity or omission of item from the Bill of Quantities shall not vitiate the Contract but shall be corrected and deemed to be a variation required by the Engineer.

In the case of the quantities for foundation works being stated to be provisional the Contractor shall, before the surface of any portion of the ground is interfered with or the work is put in hand in conjunction with the Engineer or the Engineer's Representative examine the Site and the plans and sections of the work and take such additional levels or other measurements as may be necessary and shall agree as to the surface levels etc., with the Engineer. Such agreement shall be recorded in writing and shall be signed by the Contractor and by the Engineer and shall form the basis of the measurement of the Permanent Works. The Works shall be measured net, notwithstanding any general or local custom, except where otherwise specifically described or prescribed in the Contract.

"Provisional Sum" means a sum included in the Contract and so designated" in the Bill of Quantities for the execution of work or the supply of goods, materials, or services, or for contingencies, which sum may be used, in whole or in part, or not at all, at the direction of the Engineer, who shall consult with the Employer prior to the issue of an instruction to this expenditure. The Contract Price shall include only such sums in respect of the work, supply or services to which such Provisional Sums relate as the Engineer shall approve or determine in accordance with this Clause. In respect of every Provisional Sum the Engineer shall have power to order:- (a) Work to be executed, including goods, materials or services to be supplied by the Contractor. question: How do Engr's powers over Prov. Sums affect Contractor's duties with Nom. Sub-Contractors?
ground_truth: The Engineer has the power to order work to be executed or goods, materials, or services to be supplied by a nominated Sub-Contractor. The Contractor is not obligated to employ any nominated Sub-Contractor against whom they have a reasonable objection or who declines to enter into a sub-contract with the Contractor containing specific provisions. These provisions include the nominated Sub-Contractor undertaking obligations and liabilities towards the Contractor similar to those the Contractor has towards the Employer, and indemnifying the Contractor against claims, damages, and negligence.

question: How do valve specs ensure compatibility with high-pressure and SIL systems?
ground_truth: Valve specifications ensure compatibility with high-pressure and SIL systems by requiring a minimum pressure rating of 300 ASME class or as per respective piping specification, whichever is higher. For SIL 2 & 3 loops, partial stroke checking of 'Fail Close' shutdown valves is considered from IAMS and AO card in DCS. Additionally, all solenoid valves (SOV) shall be SIL-3 certified.
contexts:
the limits as laid down by ISO 5167. The orifice plate primary element shall generally be thin plate, square-edge concentric orifices plate mounted between a pair of weld-neck type orifice flanges with flange taps. The minimum pressure rating of flanges shall be 300 ASME class. Process tapping shall be flange tapping as per ISO5167. For orifice Plates where D-D/2 taps are required and for all restriction orifices, the ratings of the orifice flanges shall be as per piping specification and the flanges shall be procured by Piping. Eccentric / Segmental type of orifice plates shall be used for specific applications. Quadrant edge or conical entrance orifice plates shall be used for services with low Reynolds number.

2

3 4

4.5 CONTROL VALVES

4.5.1 GENERAL

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Control valves shall normally be Globe type single seated. For clean services, guiding shall be top and bottom/cage type. For highly viscous services, cage guiding shall be avoided. Characteristic Ball valves shall be considered for services where solids in suspension, high rangeability, low pressure drops are required. Butterfly valves shall be considered for services where solids in suspension, low pressure drops and high capacities are required. Angle valves shall be considered for services where flashing, coking, solids in suspension or very large pressure drops are encountered. For control valve, on-off valve and self actuated pressure control valves, pressure rating of body and flanges shall be minimum 300 ASME class or as per respective piping specification whichever is higher. Bellow seal type valve shall be used for H2S service and shall be explored for H2 service and PSA valves also.

4.5.3 TRIM DESIGNS

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Material used for Trim shall be minimum 316 SS, with guide bushing of hardened stainless steel like 440 C, 17-4 PH all up to a pressure drop of 10 kg/cm2. For higher pressure drops or erosive and slurry services and in general for all steam services, hard-surfacing of plug, seal rings and sealing area of inner valve with stellite shall be used. Special cases may require 17-4 PH seat ring and 440 C solid plugs or other materials like Hastelloy, Monel etc. Multi-stage trims shall be used for where large differentials (> 40 kg/sq.cm) are encountered on case to case basis. For valves in services encountering particulate carry over along with high pressure drop, axial flow path trim design shall be used with angle body for continuous applications and globe body for intermittent applications.

a. All solenoid valves shall be auto-reset type. For Solenoid valves requiring Field manual reset as per P&ID, separate push button station shall be considered in the field for this purpose. b. 4.5.6 LIMIT SWITCHES

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Limit switches shall be generally intrinsically safe proximity type as per NAMUR (DIN 19234) except for MOVs.

4.6 PRESSURE RELIEF DEVICES

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Generally spring operated pressure relief valves may be used. Pilot operated relief valves may be used for special services and where set pressure is closer to the operating pressure by less than 10% or back pressure is above 50% of set pressure or as indicated by licensor. Spring loaded PSV’s vents connected to flare/pressure shall be provided with balanced bellows depending on the process condition. Also bellows shall be required for corrosive and dirty fluids to isolate the spring and guiding surface. PSV’s shall be manufactured in accordance with ASME Boiler and pressure vessel code section VIII.

4.7 ELECTRICAL FIELD WIRING

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Instrument electronic signal & alarm cables, single pair shall be 1.5 mm2 (min.) and multipair shall be 1.5 mm² (min.) twisted in pair individually and overall shielded with aluminium Mylar tape with drain wire and armoured. For Control wiring for solenoid valves of the interlock and shutdown system, single pair shall be 2.5 mm² (min.) and multipair shall be 2.5 mm² (min.) twisted in pair individually and overall shielded with aluminium Mylar tape with drain wire and armoured. However Cable voltage drop shall be calculated for IS solenoid valves and Cable thickness to be decided accordingly. Multicore extension cables for Thermocouples, wherever applicable, shall be 20 AWG single conductor twisted pairs, armoured, individual pair and overall aluminium mylar shielded with over all drain wire. Triad shall be 1.5 mm2 (min.) armoured. Single pair extension cables shall be armoured cable with 16 AWG single conductor wire. Power supply cables to field instruments and SOV shall be minimum 2.5 mm² armoured.

question: How do delay fragnets affect EOT entitlement and delay responsibility in a construction schedule?
ground_truth: The context does not provide a direct explanation of how delay fragnets affect EOT entitlement and delay responsibility in a construction schedule.
contexts:
are inserted into Critical Path and its effect is calculated, individually or cumulatively.

The effect of any delay event (falling on a critical path) on schedule is demonstrated as under:

Baseline or its update Scheduled Period Delay Impact Impacted Schedule Delay Event inserted Expected Extension of Time

Delay Impact = Impacted Completion Date – Scheduled Completion Date

SELECTION OF SUITABLE DELAY ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY

The Society of Construction Law Delay and Disruption Protocol February 2017 (SCL Protocol) introduced 6 (six) different methods for delay analysis.



Table 3: Different Methods of Delay Analysis, SCL Protocol 2017

S. No. Method of Analysis Analysis Type Critical Path Determined Delay Impact Determined Requires 1 Impacted As- Planned Analysis Cause & Effect Prospectively Prospectively Logic linked baseline programme. A selection of delay events to be modelled. 2 Time Impact Analysis Cause & Effect Contemporaneously Prospectively Logic linked baseline programme. Update programmes or progress information with which to update the baseline programme. A selection of delay events to be modelled. 3 Time Slice Windows Analysis Effect & Cause Contemporaneously Retrospectively Logic linked baseline programme. Update programmes or progress information with which to update the baseline programme. 4 As-Planned versus As-Built Windows Analysis Effect & Cause Contemporaneously Retrospectively Baseline programme. As-built data. 5 Retrospective Longest Path Analysis Effect & Cause Retrospectively Retrospectively Baseline Programme. As-built programme. 6 Collapsed As- Built Analysis Cause & Effect Retrospectively Retrospectively Logic linked as-built programme. A selection of delay events to be modelled.

Based on the availability of programmes, correspondence and documentary evidence, the Contractor is of the opinion that the Time Impact Analysis with Windows is the most appropriate method of delay analysis for this case. This methodology is a hybrid methodology i.e. mix of Time Impact Analysis and Time Slice Window Analysis.

This methodology requires certain conditions to be fulfilled in order to perform a delay analysis. Such conditions are fulfilled in this case:

Logic linked baseline programme, which is available in this case

Update programmes or progress information at monthly intervals with which to update the baseline programme, which are available in this case

A selection of delay events to be modelled, also referred to as “delay fragnets”; this has been done in this analysis

TIME IMPACT ANALYIS (TIA) WITH WINDOWS PROCEDURE

In this case, as explained above, a Prospective as well as Retrospective analysis called ‘Time Impact Analysis (TIA) With Windows’ methodology, is adopted to calculate Contractor’s entitlement to EOT.  a reference is made to AACE Technical Paper 2018: CDR.2849 on Time Impact Analysis in Windows:

“Time Impact Analysis in Windows (TIA) is recognized as one of the most credible techniques for analyzing construction delays according to AACE MIP3.7 Recommended practice 29R-03. 



This type of analysis was used to produce a concurrency analysis to prove contractor entitlement to prolongation costs.”

It also states: “The TIA in Windows contains elements of retrospective analysis as the project schedule is reviewed in a series of ‘snapshots’ or ‘time slices.’ The analysis also contains a prospective analysis as the delays identified are swapped for an element of ‘prospective’ modelling. The analysis therefore combines a retrospective and prospective view and can be easily used to provide clear demonstration and calculation of concurrency and mitigation.”

The ‘Time Impact Analysis (TIA) with Windows’ approach consists of the following steps as explained in above AACE article:

Step Description Details Step 1 Requirements to start the analysis, Arrangement of programmes, revisions of the baseline programme, progress updates, recovery, acceleration, mitigation programmes, etc. Details of delay events from Minutes of Progress Meetings, Monthly Reports, Progress presentations, variation orders Step 2 Preparation work, 2A Programmes Identification Review all programmes Baseline approved Update programmes exchanged i Identify the Baseline programme and ii Contemporaneous progress updates 2B Select the Window periods. Depending upon the data dates of available programme Depending on the type of project and the number of delay events 2C Selecting Critical and Near Critical Activities Identify the driving and sub-critical driving activities in each window, for the end of window programme. The driving activities need to be analyzed within the program for each milestone/section of the project that attracts liquidated damages. Step 3 Defining the Delay Events Delay Events are defined with start date and finish date, supported by the relevant correspondence or actual dates. The activities which were impacted by these delay events should be selected along with the corresponding relationship. Step 4 Modelling and Inserting

the delay fragnets into the programme, Delay event fragnets (sub-network) were created to represent each of the verified relevant events, window-wise. The delay event fragnets developed were incorporated into the relevant windows (i.e. the window with the data date prior to the event initiation date) in chronological order. Step 5 Summarizing the results, Conclusion Summarizing and interpreting the findings of analysis



DISTRIBUTION OF DELAY PERIOD: WINDOW-WISE

Assessing Contractor’s /Company’s Delays

The extent to which each delay event impacted the planned progress (i.e. the effect of the delaying event), is analyzed by comparing the forecast completion Date prior to incorporating the delay events with the impacted Completion Date after the delay events have been incorporated.

Assessing Contractor’s Delays or Mitigations

Now, comparing the impacted completion date (after incorporation of delay events) with the forecast completion date of the updated Programme, updated with progress data corresponding to end of the window.

If the date of actual completion of the Contract (or activity) is later than the calculated date of EOT entitlement, then it can be concluded that the Contractor had its own delays.

However, in other words, if the date of actual completion of the Contract (or activity) is within the calculated date of EOT entitlement (or within the excusable delay duration), then it can be concluded that the Contractor had mitigated the delay effects.

The distribution of delay in a window described above is summarized in following table:

S. No. Delay Distribution A Total Delay = Updated Date – Baseline Date = Company’s Delays + Contractor’s Delay B Company’s = Impacted Date – Baseline Date = Entitlement of Contractor’s EOT C Contractor’s Delay or Contractor’s Mitigation If C = A – B is positive Contractor’s Delay = Total Delay –Company’s Delay = Entitlement of Company’s Delay Penalties If C =B-A is positive Contractor’s Mitigation = Company’s Delay - Total Delay = Entitlement of Contractor’s mitigation

WINDOW-WISE ANALYSIS

The windows approach uses contemporaneous project documents, including project programmes and updates, to identify critical activities, as well as to measure the impact of delays in each window. The use of contemporaneous project information ensures that the analysis best reflects the parties’ knowledge of the project’s status at the time the delays occurred.

Since, with each monthly window, the Programme used will be updated, the critical path for each window is also updated as the Works progress. Therefore, the impact of delay events over any window is measured on the latest critical path, and hence, the impact is calculated contemporaneously.

The project software will calculate/revise the critical path and estimated completion date after the actual progress of Works is input into the software.

In TIA with windows at monthly intervals, the effect of delay event(s) on the programmed (or updated) completion date is analyzed during the time slice, while comparing the completion dates, at the start and end of a time slice.

A graphical illustration of Time Impact Analysis is shown below.



Thereafter, the Party’s delay for entire period is calculated by summing up the individual delays of each of windows.

Party’s delay for entire period = Sum of Party’s delays in all the considered windows

The reliability of the Approved Baseline Programme and its monthly updates are of paramount importance to the delay analysis as it is fundamental to calculating the effects of the events inserted into them during the process of a delay analysis.

For the purpose of accomplishment of this delay analysis, there were no changes made to the sanctity of the approved baseline programme or its update. However, as the Baseline Programme or its update is not very prospective to show the actual impact of the delay event, we elaborated the delay fragnet to show more reliable impact of the delay event.



THE AVAILABLE PROGRAMMES

The Baseline Programme

The approved ‘Baseline Programme- REV D’ is referred for the purpose of delay analysis. The referenced Baseline programme is suitable for all purposes and should be indicative of the planned intent for the Contractor’s scope of the works.

Completed.....................................................200

question: What valve features help prevent fugitive emissions in low-emission conditions?
ground_truth: Low emission packing / bellow seal shall be considered to prevent fugitive emissions as per process service conditions.
contexts:
the limits as laid down by ISO 5167. The orifice plate primary element shall generally be thin plate, square-edge concentric orifices plate mounted between a pair of weld-neck type orifice flanges with flange taps. The minimum pressure rating of flanges shall be 300 ASME class. Process tapping shall be flange tapping as per ISO5167. For orifice Plates where D-D/2 taps are required and for all restriction orifices, the ratings of the orifice flanges shall be as per piping specification and the flanges shall be procured by Piping. Eccentric / Segmental type of orifice plates shall be used for specific applications. Quadrant edge or conical entrance orifice plates shall be used for services with low Reynolds number.

2

3 4

4.5 CONTROL VALVES

4.5.1 GENERAL

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Control valves shall normally be Globe type single seated. For clean services, guiding shall be top and bottom/cage type. For highly viscous services, cage guiding shall be avoided. Characteristic Ball valves shall be considered for services where solids in suspension, high rangeability, low pressure drops are required. Butterfly valves shall be considered for services where solids in suspension, low pressure drops and high capacities are required. Angle valves shall be considered for services where flashing, coking, solids in suspension or very large pressure drops are encountered. For control valve, on-off valve and self actuated pressure control valves, pressure rating of body and flanges shall be minimum 300 ASME class or as per respective piping specification whichever is higher. Bellow seal type valve shall be used for H2S service and shall be explored for H2 service and PSA valves also.

4.5.3 TRIM DESIGNS

S.No. Project Philosophy 1

Material used for Trim shall be minimum 316 SS, with guide bushing of hardened stainless steel like 440 C, 17-4 PH all up to a pressure drop of 10 kg/cm2. For higher pressure drops or erosive and slurry services and in general for all steam services, hard-surfacing of plug, seal rings and sealing area of inner valve with stellite shall be used. Special cases may require 17-4 PH seat ring and 440 C solid plugs or other materials like Hastelloy, Monel etc. Multi-stage trims shall be used for where large differentials (> 40 kg/sq.cm) are encountered on case to case basis. For valves in services encountering particulate carry over along with high pressure drop, axial flow path trim design shall be used with angle body for continuous applications and globe body for intermittent applications.

question: How does a contractor handle logistics for refinery construction with limited site space?
ground_truth: The contractor handles logistics for refinery construction with limited site space by fabricating all major fabricated items at their vendor works to the maximum extent possible and transporting them to the site with the maximum length of consignment transportable by sea and road. The contractor is also responsible for carrying out the route survey/study for transportation of 'Over Dimensioned Consignments' including waterways from the source of manufacture/supply to the site well in advance of placement of order to ensure unhindered transportation to the construction site.

HOUSE KEEPING

Wastage and serviceable/ unserviceable scrap generated during dismantling and regular works shall be segregated and dumped in designated locations in consultation with Owner/PMC. Earth and landfill materials shall be dumped at locations identified by Owner/PMC, otherwise outside the Project Site and the required fees charged by the local authorities shall be borne by the CONTRACTOR without any extra cost to OWNER.

INDUSTRIAL LABOUR RELATIONS

CONTRACTOR shall be responsible for industrial relation functions and implementation of labour laws at site. CONTRACTOR'S staff shall be suitably trained and experienced in Labour Relation functions so as to ensure a good relationship with labour and to prevent the occurrence of industrial disputes resulting in subsequent delays or work stoppages. In particular, CONTRACTOR shall maintain close liaison with Owner/PMC.

CONTRACTOR shall maintain proper liaison with Statutory Authorities and local bodies and shall be responsible to implement and observe all statutory laws at site. CONTRACTOR must have in his staff; a well experienced Labour Relation Officer, preferably from local area.

CONTRACTOR shall maintain the records of wages paid in a wage register, PF, etc. as per statutory regulations.

CONTRACTOR shall report immediately to Owner/PMC any problems including labour disputes, fight, and work stoppages. A written report shall be submitted to Owner/PMC within 24 hours of the incident.

A detailed estimate of the number of labour, both indirect and direct, sorted by craft.

Outline recruiting plans for all manpower requirements. -

Identify personnel involved with labour relations and outline procedures to mitigate labour disputes & problems.

Labour welfare plan

CONTRACTOR shall hold labour relations meeting twice a month with their work force as well as a separate meeting with the Owner.

1.0

PURPOSE

This document describes the Inspection Methodology to be adopted for inspection of equipments and materials to be supplied as package for the project, complying with the specifications and quality standards laid down in the tender / contract.

2.0 SCOPE

This document is applicable for inspection of all equipment and material procured, for the packages to be supplied by the PACKAGE CONTRACTOR.

3.0

REFERENCES

Bid / Contract Document

4.0 DEFINITIONS

4.1 OWNER

Owner shall mean the project owner INDIAN OIL CORPORATION LIMITED. Wherever in this documents

or other inspection documents like ITP etc it is mentioned as EMPLOYER /IOCL, to be read as OWNER

4.2 CONSULTANT

Consultant, namely Engineers India Limited (EIL). Wherever in this documents or other inspection documents like ITP etc it is mentioned as EIL/PMC, to be read as CONSULTANT.

4.3 Package CONTRACTOR.

Package CONTRACTOR means any party whose scope includes Engineering, Procurement, Construction and Commissioning of the Unit / Facilities / System on Lump Sum basis, covered under the specified scope of work as per the Contract document. CONTACTOR, EPCC CONTRACTOR and Package CONTRACTOR are considered synonymous.

4.4

SUPPLIER

Supplier means any party supplying any of the equipment, material, products and services to the PACKAGE CONTRACTOR. Vendor, Seller, Agent are considered synonymous to Supplier.

4.5 SUB SUPPLIER

Sub supplier means any party on whom supplier suborders materials and items (like tubes, forgings , pumps, vessels, valves etc) and whose role is defined in ITPs.

4.6 SITP- Standard Inspection and test plan is ITP attached with tender document. ITPs attached contains stages of Inspection & scope of Inspection.

4.7 QUALITY ASSURANCE PLAN (QAP) / INSPECTION AND TEST PLAN (ITP)

1.

INTRODUCTION

Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL) intends to carry out Safety Integrity Level (SIL)

study for its Hydrogen Generation Unit (HGU) at Panipat Refinery under BS-VI project.

The purpose of this specification is to provide the mandatory technical requirements

to be fulfilled during detailed engineering of the project.

2.

OBJECTIVE OF SAFETY INTEGRITY LEVELS (SIL) CLASSIFICATION STUDY

Safety Integrity levels (SIL) are measures of safety of a given process, or in other

words it is a statistical representation of the integrity of the Safety Instrumented

System (SIS) when a process demand occurs. Specifically, to what extent can the

end user expect the process in question to perform safely and in the case of a failure,

fail in a safe manner.

3.

FACILITIES UNDER SCOPE OF WORK

SIL classification study shall be carried out for Hydrogen Generation Unit of IO CL,

Pa nipat Ref ine ry which is specified elsewhere in the bid document.

4.

SCOPE OF WORK

Contractor will provide an experienced Chairman and Scribe to undertake the SIL

study. The SIL workshop will be carried out by a

team comprising of

representatives from all relevant project disciplines. The scope of the study includes

all the identified Safety Instrumented Functions (SIFs) on the P&IDs and C&E

drawings. The CONTRACTOR shall prepare procedure for SIL classification study for

UNITS / FACILITIES which shall comply with IEC 61511 / 61808 requirements and

shall submit to OWNER/PMC for approval. Contractor shall submit CV for Chairman for

approval prior to SIL workshop.

5.

METHODOLOGY

The most commonly used techniques for assigning target SIL’s in the process industries

are:

 Consequence analysis

 Modified HAZOP

CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

This methodology is the simplest but the most conservative. It evaluates the target SIL’s

on the basis of the potential consequences of critical hazardous events. The likelihood

of the event is not considered. The following is an example to illustrate how

consequence is correlated with SIL.

SIL

Consequence

4

Potential for fatalities offsite

3

Potential for multiple fatalities onsite

2

Potential for single fatality onsite or serious injuries

1

Potential for minor injuries

MODIFIED HAZOP

Modifies HAZOP is an extension of the existing HAZOP procedure. The target SIL is

assigned by a team based on the review of the potential risk identified in the HAZOP.

It requires a good understanding of process risk and the acceptable risk tolerance of

the company. As the assignment is very subjective, there needs to be some

consistency between the personnel on the SIL assignment team and

the Process

Hazard Analysis (PHA) team.

RISK MATRIX

This is one of the most commonly used techniques in the process industries to establish target

SIL. It uses a risk matrix, which correlates risk severity and risk likelihood for the SIL. The

method allows the consideration of both likelihood and severity of a potential hazardous

event during the assignment of SIL. By correlating SIL values with corporate developed risk

matrix, there is more consistency compared to the use of the Modified HAZOP methodology.

Using this method requires the evaluation of the existing layers of protection and their

RISK GRAPH

IEC 61808 provides an alternate to Risk Matrix, called Risk Graph. This method

focuses on the evaluation of risk from the point of view of a person being exposed to

the incident impact zone. It is consequence driven and four parameters are used to

characterize a potential hazardous event, Consequence (C), Frequency (F), Possibility

of escape (P) and Likelihood of event (W). The following is an example of Risk Graph.

The Consequence levels are as follows:

C1 = M i n o r injury

C2 = S e r i o u s permanent injury to one or more persons, death to one person

C3 = D e a t h of several people

C4 = V e r y many people killed

In assessing the consequence severity, the following are considered:

Potential for injury or fatality

Possibility of the exposed person recovering and returning to normal activities

The effects of injury – acute or chronic

The exposure frequency (F) has two levels:

F1= Rare to more often exposure in hazardous areas

F2= Frequent to permanent exposure

Personnel exposure is evaluated in terms of the personnel presence and activity in the

unit. Typically, the following are considered:

Location of the process unit

Fraction of time plant personnel spend in the vicinity.

The possibility of escape (P) has two levels:

P1= Possible under certain conditions

P2= Almost impossible

The likelihood of occurrence (W) is quantified as follows:

W1= 0.03 pa or above (below 0.3 pa)

a slight probability

W2= 0.3 pa or above (below 3 pa)

a medium probability

W3= 3 pa or above

a high probability
